segment.source: The Enforce password history policy setting determines the number of unique new passwords that must be associated with a user account before an old password can be reused.
segment.target: The Enforce password history policy setting determines the number of unique new passwords that must be associated with a user account before an old password can be reused.

segment.source: Password reuse is an important concern in any organization.
segment.target: Password reuse is an important concern in any organization.

segment.source: Many users want to reuse the same password for their account over a long period of time.
segment.target: Many users want to reuse the same password for their account over a long period of time.

segment.source: The longer the same password is used for a particular account, the greater the chance that an attacker will be able to determine the password through brute force attacks.
segment.target: The longer the same password is used for a particular account, the greater the chance that an attacker will be able to determine the password through brute force attacks.

segment.source: If users are required to change their password, but they can reuse an old password, the effectiveness of a good password policy is greatly reduced.
segment.target: If users are required to change their password, but they can reuse an old password, the effectiveness of a good password policy is greatly reduced.

segment.source: Specifying a low number for Enforce password history allows users to continually use the same small number of passwords repeatedly.
segment.target: Specifying a low number for Enforce password history allows users to continually use the same small number of passwords repeatedly.

segment.source: If you do not also set Minimum password age, users can change their password as many times in a row as necessary to reuse their original password.

segment.source: Configure the Enforce password history policy setting to 24 (the maximum setting) to help minimize the number of vulnerabilities that are caused by password reuse.
segment.target: Configure the Enforce password history policy setting to 24 (the maximum setting) to help minimize the number of vulnerabilities that are caused by password reuse.

segment.source: For this policy setting to be effective, you should also configure effective values for the Minimum password age and Maximum password age policy settings.
segment.target: For this policy setting to be effective, you should also configure effective values for the Minimum password age and Maximum password age policy settings.

segment.source: The major impact of configuring the Enforce password history setting to 24 is that users must create a new password every time they are required to change their old one.
segment.target: The major impact of configuring the Enforce password history setting to 24 is that users must create a new password every time they are required to change their old one.

segment.source: If users are required to change their passwords to new unique values, there is an increased risk of users who write their passwords somewhere so that they do not forget them.

segment.source: Another risk is that users may create passwords that change incrementally (for example, password01, password02, and so on) to facilitate memorization, but this makes them easier for an attacker to guess.
